Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Energy Saving Solenoid Valve
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project applies a novel design to pneumatic solenoid valves that allows 20-25% of compressed air to be recycled. Given compressed air is one of the most expensive forms of stored energy, this energy-efficient design provides manufacturers with a cost effective solution for pneumatic systems using directional control valves. The basic technology has been proven to reduce compressed air use. Research objectives for this project are designed to prove the breadth of applicability and address current design factors in selecting valves. These objectives include: 1) design, production, and laboratory testing of prototypes across a spectrum of design platforms selected from commercially available valves; 2) production of durable (metal) prototypes for life-cycle testing; 3) research on safety enhancements to the original prototype design, to further ensure commercial adoption; and 4) a full-scale field test of the technology in a manufacturing environment. These objectives provide a clear path for the delivery of an energy saving valve technology that is reliable, cost-competitive, and can replace a significant portion of the multibillion-dollar worldwide solenoid valve market.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is introducing a game-changing technology into a stagnant, mature industry - pneumatic valves. The U.S. and European pneumatic valve market is $2.1 billion. The United States comprises 27% (approximately $500 million) of this total with over 70% of all manufacturing facilities employing compressed air systems. These systems utilize pneumatic solenoid valves to control air flow to actuator devices. Existing pneumatic systems are regarded as highly inefficient. The research to date has proven that this innovation will deliver a cost-competitive energy saving valve technology with the potential to apply to approximately 60% of the multi-billion dollar directional control valve market. A 20% reduction in compressed air can save U.S. manufacturers significant energy costs each year, with a national potential for $400 to 500 million in total savings. U.S. business leaders recognize the critical need for innovation in order to stay competitive. According to the 2011 Next Generation Manufacturing Study, sustainability was identified as an important area of focus. This includes designing and implementing waste and energy-use reduction to deliver superior cost performance. The proposed energy saving technology can help U.S. manufacturers stay competitive by achieving sustainability goals and reducing costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The SBIR Phase II Energy Saving Solenoid Valve Project resulted in a broad, energy efficient pneumatic platform that significantly reduces compressed air used by industrial manufacturers by 30-40%.  The DOE estimates industrial manufacturers spend over $9 billion on electricity to compress air for pneumatic systems that deliver an efficiency of less than 15%.  The work completed in Phase II, including the development, testing and optimization of the proprietary energy efficient valve technology, enabled the 2016 commercial launch of a line of pneumatic control valves used by over 70% of manufacturers.  The new valve platform is an ISO standard making the valves an easy plug-n-play replacement with existing ISO manifolds.   Field testing at large industrial manufacturers demonstrated 20-30% savings with the technology.

Phase IIB deliverables were focused on expanding the commercial product line for a broader market reach and developing leak detect to create more value to the end user.  The commercialization activities included successful field tests of the new products at commercial facilities.  A new asymmetrical valve design, proved to be very promising in its application in the tire and rubber markets. A system was tested at a tire facility and found to reduce compressed air used by 24% or 41 SCFM.  This design has also been found to significantly increase percentage savings when used in applications with short line lengths as compared to cylinder size.  The on-board leak detect is also proving to be a promising feature for companies.  Many manufacturers have been trained to perform leak audits every 6-12 months, identifying and repairing leaks that are estimated to be 20-30% of air demand.   The new leak detect feature eliminates the need for on-going audits with a continuous leak detect on the valve.  Discussions with Fortune 500 companies have proven this feature can help solve a key problem of finding leaks and/or identifying leaky components on production machines with dozens of valves. 

The long-term potential of the platform is immense for industrial manufacturers.  This energy efficient pneumatic platform easily lends itself to a practical data solution that can help manufacturers improve maintenance cost, reduce downtime and save energy.  

 


Last Modified: 01/16/2017
Modified by: Lowell Jones

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The SBIR Phase II Energy Saving Solenoid Valve Project resulted in a broad, energy efficient pneumatic platform that significantly reduces compressed air used by industrial manufacturers by 30-40%. The DOE estimates industrial manufacturers spend over $9 billion on electricity to compress air for pneumatic systems that deliver an efficiency of less than 15%. The work completed in Phase II, including the development, testing and optimization of the proprietary energy efficient valve technology, enabled the 2016 commercial launch of a line of pneumatic control valves used by over 70% of manufacturers. The new valve platform is an ISO standard making the valves an easy plug-n-play replacement with existing ISO manifolds. Field testing at large industrial manufacturers demonstrated 20-30% savings with the technology. Phase IIB deliverables were focused on expanding the commercial product line for a broader market reach and developing leak detect to create more value to the end user. The commercialization activities included successful field tests of the new products at commercial facilities. A new asymmetrical valve design, proved to be very promising in its application in the tire and rubber markets. A system was tested at a tire facility and found to reduce compressed air used by 24% or 41 SCFM. This design has also been found to significantly increase percentage savings when used in applications with short line lengths as compared to cylinder size. The on-board leak detect is also proving to be a promising feature for companies. Many manufacturers have been trained to perform leak audits every 6-12 months, identifying and repairing leaks that are estimated to be 20-30% of air demand. The new leak detect feature eliminates the need for on-going audits with a continuous leak detect on the valve. Discussions with Fortune 500 companies have proven this feature can help solve a key problem of finding leaks and/or identifying leaky components on production machines with dozens of valves. The long-term potential of the platform is immense for industrial manufacturers. This energy efficient pneumatic platform easily lends itself to a practical data solution that can help manufacturers improve maintenance cost, reduce downtime and save energy.
